subject: Re: Need Advice on Unit Testing Pain
msgSnippet: ... Paul, that does sound painful. My experience:  I like to just test some core functionality over http to make sure nothing major has been broken on a page.
messageBody:
>The highest level of the web tests check for the page flow
>(link navigation) and for page contents. These tests, written
>with HTTPUnit, are getting painful.

Paul, that does sound painful.

My experience: I like to just test some core functionality over http to
make sure nothing major has been broken on a page. I'm taking about tests
such as making sure a user can login or making sure a user can't reach a
certain page unless they login, or aspects of any complicated registration
system... those kinds of things. I've never considered testing to make
sure links work or the title of the page is just so. Designers redesign,
and marketing like to change wording... and they should be able to do that
without me changing my tests. That's my feeling.

Regarding the cost of these tests: how bad is it if the page title is
wrong? Is it worth N developer days? These are questions for you/your
management to ponder. For me, it's bad if, say, the login logic doesn't
work: that's worth testing. A page title error isn't the end of the
world. But of course, your situation may be very different.

Still...if you have a lot of dynamic text which needs to be checked (maybe
coming from a struts resource file, resource bundle, or similar) then
perhaps you can make those tests less-painful by working out a way to test
them without making http request (i.e., move them into classes somehow).

Stupid thought for the day: if you're trying to "lock down" some pages,
could you do something quick and dumb like compute a hash value/checksum
for the whole HTML page and test against that value? :-)

Regards
Richard
